ENG 150.description:
For our first short written assignment, write roughly 200-300 words describing the most memorable home from your youth. See the examples below. Try to include lots of details and concrete nouns in your essay so you paint a picture with your words. 

This assignment is due at the beginning of class on Wednesday, April 23.

As always, please use MLA format and bring a paper copy to share in class. 

Here are links for MLA templates: https://support.microsoft.com/en-us/office/use-an-apa-or-mla-template-to-start-a-paper-online-781e4161-0ff0-4773-9d0d-d337091c0b6d 

https://docs.google.com/document/d/19B-yXT9h9A1hXPugvvmo_X2esoLNWJU5ycqK6Fr65gA/edit?pli=1&tab=t.0  

 

Here is a student example:

An Old Clock

            My childhood was a lot like a trip down an interstate highway, passing smudged sagebrush and blurred fence posts, flicking past the window in a senseless blur. By the age of eighteen, I had moved twelve times. Our little houses, much like streaks of sagebrush… And new best friends, as if they were fence posts… Never really held a place in our minds, or hearts for that matter. Nothing stayed. None of the sweethearts, none of the schools, none of the smiles… It all flashed across the car window of my childhood like bolts of lightning in a summer storm. One moment you’re there, then you blink and it’s gone. Yet, as long as I can remember, no matter the city, no matter the school, one thing has always remained. Just above the fireplace, off to the left side, a little, worn, dusty clock sits comfortably. The dark, cracking wood, and the ever-so-faint numbers hint at the clock’s age.

When I was about six or seven, just figuring out my times tables, I finally decided to ask my father the question. I sat by him in our cozy new living room and asked, “Dad… why do we keep that old dusty clock around? It’s really loud and kinda ugly.” He paused for an extra long moment, making me worry I had hurt his feelings about the old thing. Then, his reply struck something in me like the string of a cello. He said, “[son]… that beat-up little clock represents what makes this house our home.” He then told me the story of our little, old, splintered clock. The story of a clock from Illinois, that made its way all the way to the west cost on a little run-down handcart. Through wind and rain, sun and stars, that little beat-up clock made it. Watching his family, clothes torn, shoes tearing, mother crying, as her boys try to be brave. But despite the sagebrush slipping past... Despite the fence grassy fields pleading them to stay... That clock trekked on. The broken, starving, exhausted family had a home, they had each other. And that little beat-up clock reminded them that. Even now, on that family’s broken, twisty trail, despite our dry sagebrush and broken fence posts, despite moving houses and leaving best friends, we always have that clock. No matter how many cracks are in our woodwork, or how faded our numbers may appear, we have that dusty little clock. We have each other. And to me, a home without that, would simply be an empty house.

ENG 150.summary: Storytelling: Slowing down time with details (Section 9)
ENG 150.description: As you watch this video, think about how you can slow down time in your writing with more details, concrete nouns, and descriptions. You will use this technique in Short Writing #2: A moment is slow motion. Write at least two questions, comments, or answers.

ENG 150.summary: Short Writing #2: A moment in slow motion (Section 9)
ENG 150.description:
Write roughly 200-300 words describing an experience from your life. 

Write about an exciting or pivotal moment where time seemed to slow down. Perhaps it was when you scored the winning goal, got hurt in an accident, or opened your mission call. 

Be sure to use the techniques discussed in the video "Storytelling: slowing down time with details." Especially focus on adding more concrete nouns to the key moments of the story.  

 

As always, please use MLA format and bring a paper copy to class.

Write 1-2 pages (250-500 words) narrating your walk home from school. As always, use MLA format and bring a paper copy to class. 

You should stay in the past tense--i.e. "I trudged up the hill towards my dorm," not "I trudge up the hill towards my dorm." 

Try to use only kinetic verbs that show motion, not "to be" verbs like "is, am, are, was, were, be, being, and been." For example, "Dirt streaked the snow," not "The snow was dirty";  "The apartment building squatted on the hill," not "The apartment building was on the hill."

Try to include lots of concrete, specific nouns and quality adjectives--i. e. "By the cracked sidewalk, a patch of grass withered in the heat of the September afternoon. Fat grasshoppers leaped off the sidewalk like burnt-yellow springs around my feet." Avoid generalities and weak adjectives--i. e. "I saw grass that looks very dry as I walk down the sidewalk, and there were lots of bugs jumping out of my way as I approached them. 

Finally, try to tell a story with a beginning, middle, and end.. 

See "A Walk Home" below an example of an excellent student paper. 

 

As always, bring a physical copy of your paper to class. 

 

“Going Home” 

I burst from the front doors of Berklee and immediately stop and blink. At 5:15 p.m., the sunlight is a brutal contrast to the dimly lit halls of the school behind me. My eyes begin to focus, and the world slowly regains form. Chaos reigns on Massachusetts Avenue. Scores of musicians linger at this end of the block, and several non-Berklee pedestrians have to elbow their way past. Beyond the sidewalk, a disgruntled cab driver blasts his horn in frustration: rush hour is in full bloom.

I turn to my right and start to head up Mass. Ave., following my carefully planned route back home. The wide sidewalk here allows for easy maneuvering around slower paced walkers, and I quickly approach the Boylston Street intersection. A young-looking guy skids towards me on a bicycle and asks if I’ve read the Scriptures lately. Fortunately, the light is green, so I avoid the question and jog across the street.

This part of Mass Ave. passes over eight lanes of Mass Pike tollway. Several pedestrians quickly cover their ears as a construction drill below grinds away at broken pavement. I pass the four green ‘T’ stop doors, and a welcome rush of cold air gushes from inside the subway station. Tower Records stands just ahead, and several dozen people sit on the building’s window ledges waiting for the bus. An older man, probably in his seventies, stands up when two teenagers with multi-colored hair and nose rings crowd his perch. Two women eating ice cream discuss bathing suit sizes.

Suddenly a very tall man wearing brand-new Nike shoes blocks my path and asks for some spare change. I try to mumble “sorry” and walk around him, but the human traffic in this area is too congested to make an easy getaway. The panhandler persists, and I silently curse myself for getting caught off guard. I reach into my right pocket, grab a handful of change, gum wrappers, lint and God knows what else, and dump it in his cup. He praises me in the name of the Lord and moves on.

At Newbury Street I turn right. The sidewalk here is wider, so one can more easily weave in and out of the crowds of people. The concrete, patio-like area between Tower Records and JP Licks Ice Cream is always an interesting spot. Today a group of guys with mohawks, chains and tattoos licks ice cream cones near the back wall, while a long-haired woman wearing tie-dyed clothing sells beads at the edge. Further down the block another panhandler sings, dances, and shakes his change cup. He’s loud enough almost to drown out the Roy Orbison tune blaring from a nearby apartment. Even so, no one pays attention to him.

Many intriguing shops line the south side of Newbury Street, including Starbuck’s Coffee, Patagonia Shoes, and Jean Pierre David Hair Salon. Just before I reach Newbury Comics, I cross the street to avoid the pesky Dianetics surveyors who hunt for prey outside the Boston Architectural Center. Sonsie Café, the artsy attraction on the North side of the street, employs a rather ragged-looking artist to stand in the outdoor section and paint. Today he’s painting a colorful nude version of the two women dining closest to the sidewalk. They don’t suspect a thing.

In order to avoid an annoyingly far-reaching sprinkling system, I cross Gloucester Avenue before turning left towards Commonwealth Avenue. Gloucester Avenue is a quiet side street lined with lofty old three-flats interrupted only by Public Alley #442, Several of the trees that stand between the parking meters have not been maintained very well: their low drooping branches force passersby to duck. At the end of the block, a rusty old Boston Herald newspaper machine displays today’s headline: NY JET EXPLODES.

Lofty elm trees stand in front of the stony red buildings that line the southern side of Commonwealth Avenue., and one must walk nearer to the street to avoid several dog-walkers and stroller-pushers. To the left, a 100-foot wide park area divides the east and westbound lanes; Winston Churchill himself has declared this mall one of the world’s most beautiful. Today, several dozen roller-bladers skate through the middle path, and the continuous line of shady trees protects them from the glaring sun.

I live at 270 Commonwealth Avenue, a short walk from Gloucester Avenue. Several guitarists stand near the front door, with the gig bags slung over their shoulders. They look like long-haired soldiers casually guarding a musical fortress, and we exchange typical musician “hey-man” greetings. My eight-and-a-half-minute journey ends as I begin to search in my right pocket for my suspiciously absent keys. ♣

(This example is taken from http://readablewriting.com/discussion)

For this assignment, interview one of your roommates or a family member who lives with you.

Write roughly 300-500 words describing your interview.

Start with a physical description of the room where you conducted the interview. Describe the physical appearance of the person you interview and write about their voice, mannerisms, personality, etc.

Summarize some of their answers and quote other answers word-for-word.

Here are some suggested questions: 

* Tell me about where you grew up and what your family life was like.

* How did your parents influence you?

* Where did you go to high school?

* Who have been your strongest influences in life?

* How did you chose to come to BYU-I?

* What led you to your major?

* How would friends and acquaintances describe you?

* What are you most proud of accomplishing?

* What would you do differently if you had a chance?

* Share with me something about yourself that you want to improve.

* Describe a scene of your vision for the future.

Write 250-500 words describing a moment of significant change. This could be a moment when you realized something significant. Or it could be a moment when you dedicated yourself to a new course of action. Or it could be any moment of triumph, defeat, gratitude, love, testimony, etc. 

Write about what happened and how it changed your thinking, or your commitment, or your testimony, etc. 

Make your paper more effective by describing the physical location, or your physical appearance or facial expressions. Use kinetic verbs where possible, and bring in dialogue, either what people said, or the internal dialogue of your own thoughts. 

As always, please bring a paper copy to class.
Write at least 2 comments, questions, or answers.Highlight text to leave a comment.

Write three different stories about your life. Each story should be about one paragraph long. Don't worry about adding details, great verbs, or quotations.  

For each of the three short stories, make sure that there is a beginning, a middle, and an end. Each story should have some kind of tension that builds up into a climax. 

For example, if you wrote that (Beginning) you got hurt playing sports and (Middle) the recovery was hard, that wouldn't be a complete story. There are only two things, and they don't build up to a conclusion. 

Instead you could write that you were (Beginning) cocky about being the star of the team, but then (Middle) you got hurt and had to (End) learn to humbly cheer on your team from the sidelines. 

You need to connect the events of your story in a meaningful way. We should see how one thing leads to the next and how these events impacted you. 

One way is to think of the beginning as a goal, the middle as an obstacle, and the end as the resolution. For example, (Beginning) you wanted to be a great missionary, but (Middle) learning a foreign language was hard, so you (End) studied and prayed until one day you spoke fluently and touched people with your words. 

Remember to write three different true stories from your life for this assignment. Each story should be just a paragraph long.

ENG 150.summary: Hand in - Peer Review for Change Up Paper

Read and comment on your peer's paper. Focus on suggestion for improvement.
[Go to the FeedbackFruits activity in the course] (https://byui.instructure.com/courses/335578/assignments/14889563)

Use this prompt to write a 250-650 word essay that could be used for admission to college, graduate school, or a job. 

What is one of the most difficult things you have ever done or experienced? What did you learn from it?

Write a story with a beginning, middle, and end. Try to use concrete nouns, quotations, names, and interesting verbs to show the details of your experience in a vivid way. As always, please bring a paper copy of your essay to class. 

 

Please see the examples below.

 

Example #1

I couldn’t breathe. If there was ever a time to quit, this was it.

It was an innocent conditioning drill. Two partners raced to a ball at the fifty yard line with incentive to win: the loser ran an extra one hundred yards. My partner was Kelly, one of the fastest girls on the team. It wasn’t long before I was having an asthma attack.

I often imagined myself wearing a varsity jacket with pride, but my field hockey coaches impeded my goal. They humiliated me on the field. They promoted freshmen to varsity and made me the ball girl. They told me I’d “never be more than an okay player.” When I crossed the end line after yet another one hundred yard punishment sprint, I’d long since given up hope on my goal. The dream of a varsity jacket I could wear proudly had degraded to the dream of a varsity letter gathering dust in the attic. After years of sacrifice and hard work, I was nothing more than a senior in high school still playing junior varsity.

Coach Bower called my name. I turned to her, holding my back erect and pressing my hands to my stomach, desperately trying to control the frantic nature of my breathing. She must have noticed the wheezing. She must have seen the tears threatening to spill from my panicked eyes.

“Walk to the stroke mark.” She was giving me a six yard head start.

I forced my body forward, head to the ground to hide the tears of shame that burned my eyes. There was dead silence behind me as my teammates stood in a uniform line and stared at my back.

“Take a few more steps.”

The silence was broken by my own gasping sobs. This was more than embarrassment. This was abject humiliation.

I could see my teammates out of the corner of my eye, whispering.

Coach announced to the field: “Let’s see if we can give Kelly a challenge.”

My hands shook with rage. I narrowed my eyes, glaring at the orange ball ahead of me. It suddenly didn’t matter if it was forty-four yards or fifty yards or three miles away. I was going to get there first, or die trying. I rocked back and forth on the balls of my feet, wheezing, hiccupping, and waiting.

She blew the whistle.

I clenched my teeth through the pain in my chest and sprinted, sobbing between gasping breaths. I beat Kelly by one step.

Days later, I was finally given one chance to play varsity and prove myself to the same coaches who said I’d never be “more than okay.” It wasn’t long before I was a varsity starter.

I might have waited my whole life and never caught that lucky break necessary to capture my dreams, but it would have been impossible to succeed if I had given up before that chance came my way. There is no such thing as failure. There are only missed opportunities.

Example #2

Living in the graffiti-adorned projects of the Lower East Side, I’ve adjusted well to low-income living. Stuyvesant High School’s done a first-rate job on making me feel like an outcast for it.

“You can get a fee waiver once you give us a copy of your parent’s 1040 tax forms,” Ms. Cleary automatically explained.

“My parents don’t have tax forms,” I said pointedly. “They don’t fill them out.”

“Of course they file tax forms,” she shot back. “Everyone does.” After a few more minutes of fruitless discussion, I left the College Office, unsuccessful. I would pay for SAT II exams, again.

Even with fee waivers, applying to college is pricey. Sending test scores to more than 4 colleges cost money, AP exams fees are reduced but not obliterated, and I’d love to meet the genius who thought of charging a fee for applying for financial aid. When approaching Ms. Cleary for help with the CCS Profile - I didn’t know where to indicate welfare and food stamp income - she asked me which school I chose to apply to.

“M.I.T.,” I replied.

“Oh, M.I.T.?” she mused. “How ironic, that you’re applying to M.I.T. and yet you can’t fill out a form…” I don’t consider my school’s administration supportive or welcoming.

My family felt strained enough paying $57 for senior dues when I attended middle school. Being a senior at Stuy is much, much worse. So far, this year’s classes have demanded about $270 total in textbooks, workbooks, art supplies, and other expenses. When my teachers ask whether anyone will have trouble paying for their supplies, no one speaks up and an awkward silence ensues.

While academic costs have mostly been waived, high school memories are not priceless. Yearbook photos just came in, and packages cost from $86 to about $230. I’ll probably wear an old dress and take the subway to my senior prom, which will probably set me back another $160. I will not get a class ring.

Many of my friends carry $10 and $20 daily, while I get $5 on a good day. Most of their parents are middle to upper class, working as teachers, lawyers, programmers, doctors, writers, social workers, or scientists, unlike my mother who is excused from work because of illness. Some of my classmates come from private schools, and many buy prep books for exams and have been in expensive SAT prep courses since middle school. They seem unable to comprehend my situation; the blank, baffled looks on their faces upon learning I have no cable television, cell phone, or air conditioning shock me.

“We do it because we want you to be happy,” my grandmother had explained to me when giving me $60 to attend a discounted college trip. Even in a nation governed by socioeconomic class, I believe that happiness and perseverance are enough for success. Although I use second-hand paints and brushes in acrylic painting class, I know that my painting will look just as striking.

Please submit a full draft of your personal essay. You will write 4-6 pages about an experience and what you learned from it. 

Here are more detailed instructions:

******************************************
Personal Essay Assignment Sheet and Rubric
******************************************

Essay roughly 800-1200 words

MLA (works cited page not required)

Assignment Sheet

Write an essay that allows you to develop a theme through your life’s experience and commentary.  One of the great hallmarks of the personal essay is the personal nature of the voice, the intimacy in which the writer reveals him or herself in order to develop or reveal the theme.

Things to keep in mind:

* The personal essay can originate from the writer’s own life, or it can come from the writer making observations about life around him or her. It can be more of a personal memoir or a personal essay.

* The personal essay is written to offer insight into life.

* The personal essay may be serious or humorous.

* The personal essay wrestles with complex questions in life; it doesn’t offer simplistic answers.

* The personal essay is reflective in nature; even when writing about a past experience, the writer is thinking and commenting on the experience as he or she thinks about it today, not how he or she may have thought about it then.

* The personal essay is not a research-driven essay; however, it may include outside sources, as necessary. Outside sources are informally referenced in the text of the essay.

Rubric

Scale

1 = Weak      2 = Developing      3 = Working      4 = Proficient      5 = Strong

 

Areas of Focus

Rating

Purpose/Insight/Theme/Question

·         No too preachy

·         Invites pondering

 

 

Conflict vs. Crisis

·         Conflict/complexity is good

·         Simple crisis is not good

 

 

Show vs. Tell

·         Ladder of Abstraction

·         Effective ratio

 

 

Beginning & Ending

·         Thoughtful

 

Engaging style/voice

Formatting & Mechanics

ENG 150.summary: SW #13 Essay on identity with source sandwiches (Section 9)
ENG 150.description:
Write a 2-3 page essay on the topic of identity and the gospel. 

Start by reading the section of President Nelson's devotional address from May 15, 2022, titled "First, know the truth about who you are." I have included the section below, and here is the link to the full  address: https://www.churchofjesuschrist.org/study/broadcasts/worldwide-devotional-for-young-adults/2022/05/12nelson?lang=eng 

Then write your thoughts about why it is important to remember our most significant identities instead of focusing on identities like race, gender, or sexual orientation. 

You should use at least two quotations in this paper. They can be from President Nelson's talk or any other source. Be sure to introduce each source and follow up after the quotation using the "source sandwich method" explained here:

 https://vimeo.com/1022301659?share=copy 

 

As always, please bring a paper copy to workshop in class. 

 

President Nelson's words:

First: Know the truth about who you are. I believe that if the Lord were speaking to you directly tonight, the first thing He would make sure you understand is your true identity.[11] (https://www.churchofjesuschrist.org/study/broadcasts/worldwide-devotional-for-young-adults/2022/05/12nelson?lang=eng#note11) My dear friends, you are literally spirit children of God. You have sung this truth since you learned the words to “I Am a Child of God.”[12] (https://www.churchofjesuschrist.org/study/broadcasts/worldwide-devotional-for-young-adults/2022/05/12nelson?lang=eng#note12) But is that eternal truth imprinted upon your heart? Has this truth rescued you when confronted with temptation?[13] (https://www.churchofjesuschrist.org/study/broadcasts/worldwide-devotional-for-young-adults/2022/05/12nelson?lang=eng#note13)

I fear that you may have heard this truth so often that it sounds more like a slogan than divine truth. And yet, the way you think about who you really are affects almost every decision you will ever make.

In 2006, when I married Wendy, I was in for several surprises—most of them quite wonderful. One of those surprises was the number of clothing items she owned that displayed a logo—universities from which she graduated, places she had traveled, and so forth. Whenever she wore one of those items, I teased her by saying, “Who are you advertising today?” She invited me to join in the fun!

[Russell M. Nelson] (https://assets.ldscdn.org/25/6e/256e0dacca14eb2077475a80c44c02c9a38a373d/russell_m_nelson.png)

Labels can be fun and indicate your support for any number of positive things. Many labels will change for you with the passage of time. And not all labels are of equal value. But if any label replaces your most important identifiers, the results can be spiritually suffocating.

For example, if I were to rank in order of importance the designations that could be applied to me, I would say: First, I am a child of God—a son of God—then a son of the covenant, then a disciple of Jesus Christ and a devoted member of His restored Church.

Next would come my honored titles as a husband and father, then Apostle of the Lord Jesus Christ.

All other labels that have applied to me—such as a medical doctor, surgeon, researcher, professor, lieutenant, captain, PhD, American, and so forth—would fall somewhere down the list.

Now, let us turn the question to you. Who are you?

First and foremost, you are a child of God.

Second, as a member of the Church, you are a child of the covenant. And third, you are a disciple of Jesus Christ.

Tonight, I plead with you not to replace these three paramount and unchanging identifiers with any others, because doing so could stymie your progress or pigeonhole you in a stereotype that could potentially thwart your eternal progression.

For example, if you are identified mainly as an American, those who are not Americans may think, “I know everything there is to know about you” and attribute erroneous beliefs to you.

If you identify yourself by your political affiliation, you will instantly be categorized as having certain beliefs—though I don’t know anyone who believes everything that their preferred political party presently embraces.

We could go on and on, rehearsing the constraints of various labels that we put on ourselves or that other people place upon us.

Some might label me as an “old man.” But I’m a lot younger than Adam was—and Noah too.[14] (https://www.churchofjesuschrist.org/study/broadcasts/worldwide-devotional-for-young-adults/2022/05/12nelson?lang=eng#note14) Ageism, racism, nationalism, sexism, and a host of other “isms” are universally limiting.

How tragic it is when someone believes the label another person has given them. Imagine the heartache of a child who is told, “You are dumb.” Identifiers and labels are powerful!

The adversary rejoices in labels because they divide us and restrict the way we think about ourselves and each other. How sad it is when we honor labels more than we honor each other.

Labels can lead to judging and animosity. Any abuse or prejudice toward another because of nationality, race, sexual orientation, gender, educational degrees, culture, or other significant identifiers is offensive to our Maker! Such mistreatment causes us to live beneath our stature as His covenant sons and daughters!

There are various labels that may be very important to you, of course. Please do not misunderstand me. I am not saying that other designations and identifiers are not significant. I am simply saying that no identifier should displace, replace, or take priority over these three enduring designations: “child of God,” “child of the covenant,” and “disciple of Jesus Christ.”

Any identifier that is not compatible with these three basic designations will ultimately let you down. Other labels will disappoint you in time because they do not have the power to lead you toward eternal life in the celestial kingdom of God.

Worldly identifiers will never give you a vision of who you can ultimately become. They will never affirm your divine DNA or your unlimited, divine potential.

Because there is a grand plan of salvation authored by Heavenly Father, does it not stand to reason that you also have a divine destiny?[15] (https://www.churchofjesuschrist.org/study/broadcasts/worldwide-devotional-for-young-adults/2022/05/12nelson?lang=eng#note15)

Make no mistake about it: Your potential is divine. With your diligent seeking, God will give you glimpses of who you may become.

So who are you? First and foremost, you are a child of God, a child of the covenant, and a disciple of Jesus Christ. As you embrace these truths, our Heavenly Father will help you reach your ultimate goal of living eternally in His holy presence.

*************************************************************************************************************************************************************************************************************************************************************************************************************************************************************************************************************************************************************
Write a 1-2 page paper about what you plan to do for this research project. Write about what you plan on changing in your own life and your reasons for picking that project. Write about any background knowledge you have. Share a few predictions about what you think will happen during the experiment. Lay out the rules that you have for your experiment. Share your plan for following through with your intentions and taking notes along the way. 
*************************************************************************************************************************************************************************************************************************************************************************************************************************************************************************************************************************************************************

 

As always, please bring a paper copy for us to work on in class. 

***********************************
Change Something Up Research Essay 
***********************************

**************************
Assignment Sheet - ENG 150
**************************

-----------------
Vital Information
-----------------

Audience: Your Instructor and your peers

Purpose: To practice gathering primary and secondary research and then synthesizing that data into a coherent narrative/reflective essay

Genre: Experiential essay in a modified IMRD format

Stance: Fun but scientific and reliable

Medium: Multimedia alphabetic text (may also images and other media)

Length: Roughly 1250-1750 words

Proposal due: Week 7

Experiment duration: Two weeks

 

---------------------
Assignment Background
---------------------

A popular genre in contemporary non-fiction is the short-term personal experiment report. Search “30-day experiment” on youtube or google and you will find an endless stream of people changing their lives in an effort to improve and then reporting on the results. 

---------
Your Task
---------

For this assignment you will be doing something similar: You will need to do something out of the ordinary every day for 14 days as a primary research experiment. Before the experiment starts, you’ll make predictions about how the experiment will affect you. During the two weeks, you will keep a journal of field notes about your experience. You will also research if anyone else has tried the same or similar experiment and compare your results to theirs, as well as find out more information about how and why making this change matters or could affect you and how it affects other people typically. You will then turn your writings into a roughly 1250-1750 word reflective research essay written in IMRD (Introduction, Methods, Results, Discussion) format—like a typical lab report, but with narrative elements.

 

Research Requirements 
----------------------

There are three types of sources that you will need to find and incorporate into this assignment: (1) statistics on how many people are doing something similar to what you did for your experiment in order to put your experience in context (2) scientific research on how people are typically affected by doing what you did, and (3) experiences of other people who have done something similar to your experiment (review what happened during their experiment and what their results were, and compare your results to theirs). 

 

Research Requirement

Where to look

Where it will be in the paper

1

Statistics

Pew Research

Statista

Google 

Introduction

2

Scientific Research

Scholar

Library Website

Never in the Results section

Introduction (motivated)

Methods

Discussion (make sense)

3

Other people’s experiences

YouTube

Medium

Google search

(avoid advertisements)

Discussion

(methods)

 

Essay Structure
---------------

* Introduction 

* Give background of your previous experience with the topic and research (especially statistics) that contextualizes your experience

* Give the reader some idea why you chose this experiment out of all the things you could have done

* Remember to write to an audience who has no idea about what a Change Something Up experiment is. Introduce the entire concept to them.

* Methods 

* Explain the rules of the experiment you established for yourself 

* If your rules changed at any point during the experiment, you might explain it here, or you might save that for later in the results section

* Tell what you hoped to gain from it when you chose it

* You might also bring up your research question, tell them what you specifically decided to pay attention to during the experiment

* Results 

* Present, with vivid details, a few select and important events of the experiment 

* Begin this section with a brief overview of the entire experiment and give any hard numbers if you have them available (e.g. “I did my experiment successfully 11 of the 14 days of the experiment.”)

* Present mini-stories or narrative vignettes of moments where you learned something about life or about yourself because of the experiment

* Discussion 

* Reflect on what you learned while doing the experiment

* Don’t introduce any new results here

* Self-evaluate (make guesses about why you succeeded and/or failed)

* Discuss the implications for your life based on the results

* Discuss the trade offs you needed to make in order to make the experiment work (what did you have to stop or start doing in order to be successful)

* Present the results and experience of someone else who did a similar experiment to yours, and compare your results to theirs

* Project into the future what your relationship to your topic will be moving forward

------------------------
Choosing Your Experiment
------------------------

For the experiment, you will need to either stop doing something you feel that you do too much of, start doing something you feel you don’t do enough of, or do something you currently do already in a totally different way. In order to be transparent about your efforts, you will want to choose something that a camera could see you doing (or not).

 

Each experience you have during your experiment is worthy of writing about, even (maybe especially) your failures. Although there are no requirements for how much you write in your notes, remember that the more often you write about your experiences during the experiment, the better your final piece will be. Most students write somewhere between 5 and 8 pages of notes over the course of the experiment.

 

Whatever you choose to do, realize that it is going to (and should) disrupt your life, and that you are going to have to make accommodations for that disruption. Your life is already full. If you are choosing to add something to your life, you are going to have to give up something else; likewise, if you are trying to take something out of your life, you are going to have to decide now what is going to fill that space. Your discussion section should talk about the tradeoffs that you had to make in order to change this part of your life up. 

Here are some examples:

-Write in your journal every day

-Finish your homework early each day, or study at a consistent time before relaxing

-Do a random act of service each day

-Connect with an old friend or a family member through a phone call each day

-Go for a walk each morning or do another form of exercise

-Write a list of 5 things you are grateful for each day

-Meet a new person each day and get to know them for a few minutes

-Go to the temple each day to do an ordinance or just sit on the grounds

-Post your testimony in some form through a message or on social media each day

-Practice a new hobby or a hobby you have forgotten each day. For example, try drawing something every day or play the violin each day if you have not practiced in a while

-Learn something new each day like 10 words of a new language or memorize a verse of scripture each day

-Do a 14-day social media fast

-Meditate each day. You could use a meditation app like Headspace or Calm

 

-------------------
Managing Your Notes
-------------------

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
There are many options for keeping track of your 14-day experiment. You may choose to keep one file where you will keep your notes, or use a note taking program like Google Keep or something similar. If you write on paper, you could use a spiral-bound notebook or bound journal especially for the project. (I lose paper really quickly myself, so I am not going to do that.) The important thing is to keep a lot of notes safe for the whole time. If you lose your notes, writing your paper will be extremely difficult and you will end up with a worse final product. We will have a day in class where you bring your notes, so make sure you have them in a format that works for that. 
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

In your notes, you will want to record meaningful moments: firsts, lasts, mosts, when things feel new or difficult or easy. When and why you choose to give up on the experiment or recommit. Also, you’ll want notes from when you are actually doing the thing you chose to do, and also from when you see it have effects in other parts of your life. 

--------------
Use of Sources
--------------

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
This is a research assignment. You will be doing both primary research (your own experiences), and secondary research (the experiences and research of others). Part of your job with this assignment is to be meticulous in representing where your outside information is coming from through in-text citations and bibliographic references. You will need to integrate quotes using MLA formatting we have been learning all semester, and include an MLA works cited page.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

For this short writing assignment, find and summarize 3-4 sources that you could use for your Change Up essay. 

Instead of scholarly sources, this time look for statistics and stories that fit well with your project. 

For example, if your experiment involves meditation, you could find numbers about how many people in the USA meditate regularly. Some helpful sites might include [www.pewresearch.org] (http://www.pewresearch.org), [www.statista.com] (https://www.statista.com/), and simple google searches. 

For stories, you could google "14-day meditation challenge" or "30-day meditation experiment" and find stories of people who tried a similar experiment. 

If your experiment involves religion or spirituality, you might be interested in these stories about young adults who tried to increase their faith in a 30-day challenge: 

https://newsroom.churchofjesuschrist.org/article/try-faith-30-day-challenge-7-share-how-each-grew-closer-jesus-christ 

As always, bring a paper copy for us to workshop in class.
Make at least two comments, questions, or answers

ENG 150.summary: SW #22 Persuasive Paper Research Questions and Background (Section 9)
ENG 150.description:
This short writing assignment will help you get a head start on your persuasive research paper

Try to find a topic that you can research and write about for the next few weeks. Do some general research on Google or Wikipedia to learn more about your topic. 

Then, write 1-2 pages about the background of your topic, common arguments you have heard, and questions that you want to answer. You could also write about how your topic fits with the five stasis points.

For example, if you chose to write about homeschooling, you might include these questions and your initial answers:

Facts: How many children are being homeschooled in the USA?

Definition: What counts as home-schooling? What about online schools, dual-enrollment, etc. 

Cause/effect: Why is homeschooling becoming more popular? 

Evaluation: Does homeschooling help or harm kids academically? Does it help or harm kids socially?

Proposal: Should there be more government oversight for homeschooling? Should parents get tax money to help them educate their kids? Should parents choose homeschooling? 

 

As always, bring a paper copy to class.

Here are some topics that you might want to choose, but you are not limited to these options:

-Is online dating a good way to meet a spouse?  

-Is it better to grow up with lots of siblings or few siblings?

-Is it better to get married at a younger age or an older age? 

-What are the solutions to the drug and Fentanyl problems in the US?

-Should transgender athletes compete with female athletes? 

-Should states ban hormone blockers, cross-sex hormones, and/or sex-change surgeries for minors? 

-What can be done about illegal immigration?  

-Should the federal government forgive student loan debt? 

-What is the value of a college degree? 

-Is nuclear power safe and effective, or should nuclear power plants be shut down? 

-What are the effects of smartphones, screen time, and/or social media on mental health?

-Is physical discipline like spanking effective in parenting?

-Should marijuana be legalized recreationally in every state? 

-Should we raise the federal minimum wage to $15?

-Should states ban abortion? If so, at what stage in the pregnancy? How should abortion laws be enforced? 

-Should colleges practice affirmative action in admissions? Should employers use affirmative action in hiring? 

-What is the best solution for homelessness? Is "housing first" a good policy? 

-What is the best solution to crime? What are the merits of criminal justice reform, bail reform, and "harm reduction" policies? 

-Should California and other states ban the sale of new gas cars by 2035? Should the government continue to subsidize the sale of electric vehicles with tax breaks? 

-Should the government subsidize the sale of solar panels for homeowners? 

-What are the effects of religion on teenagers and young adults? 

-Should all states ban minors from tanning beds? 

-Should social media platforms censor speech? Should hate speech be banned? Should certain books be taken out of school libraries? 

-Is homeschooling good for kids? 

-What are the benefits or harms of standardized testing? 

-What forms of exercise are the most effective? Is weight training more effective than aerobic exercise? What about things like HIT, supplements, etc.? 

-What are the effects of gratitude on happiness?

Read chapter 6 of our book They Say / I Say. 

You can access a free online version of the book here: [https://archive.org/details/they-say-i-say-5th-edition/page/n1/mode/2upLinks to an external site.] (https://archive.org/details/they-say-i-say-5th-edition/page/n1/mode/2up) or here [https://archive.org/details/theysayisay3rdedition/page/n29/mode/2upLinks to an external site.] (https://archive.org/details/theysayisay3rdedition/page/n29/mode/2up)

For this short writing exercise, read this article by Prof. Brad Wilcox on marriage and children:

[The Two-Parent Advantage | City Journal (city-journal.org)] (https://www.city-journal.org/article/the-two-parent-advantage) 

Then, write a summary in a table format with 16 rows, one for each paragraph. There should be two columns in your table, like the one below. Label the left column "Says" and the right column "Does." Then write a summary of what each paragraph says in the left column boxes. In the right column boxes, describe what that paragraph does in the essay. What move is the author making in that paragraph? I have filled in the first couple of boxes to help you get started.

You can copy and paste this table into your document or make your own table. Fill in all the remaining boxes, one for each paragraph. Don't put in anything for the graphs and charts. 

As always, bring a printed version for us to work on in class. 

Says

Does

A colleague's wife asked him if divorce is not a big deal these days 

Hooks reader's attention with a story and a "they say"

The hiking partner thought stigma of divorce is less, so the kids will be fine

Explains naysayer argument

A lot of people, especially liberals, agree that marriage is not that valuable

Shows that many people agree with the naysayer and have the wrong evaluation of the value of marriage

Read chapter 7 of our book They Say / I Say. 

You can access a free online version of the book here: [https://archive.org/details/they-say-i-say-5th-edition/page/n1/mode/2upLinks to an external site.] (https://archive.org/details/they-say-i-say-5th-edition/page/n1/mode/2up) or here [https://archive.org/details/theysayisay3rdedition/page/n29/mode/2upLinks to an external site.] (https://archive.org/details/theysayisay3rdedition/page/n29/mode/2up)

Read chapter 8 our book They Say / I Say. 

You can access a free online version of the book here: [https://archive.org/details/they-say-i-say-5th-edition/page/n1/mode/2upLinks to an external site.] (https://archive.org/details/they-say-i-say-5th-edition/page/n1/mode/2up) or here [https://archive.org/details/theysayisay3rdedition/page/n29/mode/2upLinks to an external site.] (https://archive.org/details/theysayisay3rdedition/page/n29/mode/2up)

ENG 150.summary: SW #24 Sources for the Persuasive Paper (Section 9)
ENG 150.description:
Write a 1-2 page paper with at least 6 sources, 4 of which should be peer-reviewed, academic articles.

For each source, include the MLA citation and a few sentences of summary about what the source says and where you might use it.

Useful resources include [scholar.google.com] (http://scholar.google.com) and [library.byui.edu] (http://library.byui.edu) 

As you search for sources, think about which sources will fit into which parts of your paper. 

Here are some of the ideas for outlining that we looked at in class:

Different ideas for organizing your paper:

Problem/Solution: Good for topics that not everyone knows are big problems

-A big chunk of the paper should establish the size/importance of the problem

-Then you give your solutions

-Naysayers could be saying “it’s not a real problem,” or “That solution won’t work”

5 Stasis Points: Good for most topics, especially if people are not aware of them

-Facts, definitions, cause and effect, evaluation, and proposal

-Consider ending with a proposal, no matter what organization you use

Evaluation or Proposal focus: good for specific topics

-For evaluation, establish criteria

-For proposal, show that your solution is better than the alternatives and feasible

Delayed Thesis: Good for highly controversial topics

-show pros and cons of both sides

-Eventually share what you think is the stronger side

They Say / I Say: Good for most topics, especially if there are a lot of opinions out there

-Start with what others are saying, respond like a conversation, deal with naysayers

Naysayer Focus: Good for controversial topics, or for readers who disagree with you

-Bring up and answer a series of naysayers

Traditional: works for many topics, especially if you have a lot of objective evidence

-Thesis, reasons, evidence

-Include naysayers

ENG 150.summary: SW #25: First 2 pages of Persuasive Paper (Section 9)
ENG 150.description:
Write the first two pages of your persuasive paper.

The final persuasive paper should be 5-7 pages long (approximately 1250-1750 words). You should use 5-6 sources, at least 3 of which should be scholarly sources. 

Your paper should have an interesting title and a hook to grab your reader's attention. You should state a clear thesis and support it with evidence, carefully engaging with the counter-arguments. 

Please use MLA format. 

Please bring a physical copy of this draft to class as always.

Read chapter 10 of our book They Say / I Say.

ENG 150.summary: SW #26 Source sandwich and naysayer paragraphs (Section 9)
ENG 150.description:
Write at least two more paragraphs for your Persuasive Paper. These can be from anywhere in the body of the essay.

Include at least one source sandwich, where you introduce, quote, and follow up on a source from your research. 

Also include at least one naysayer. Summarize, quote, or bring up an objection to a point in your paper, then answer that objection with quality evidence. 

 

As always, bring a paper copy for us to workshop in class.

Upload your full rough draft of your Persuasive Essay here: [Peer Review for Persuasive Paper] (https://byui.instructure.com/courses/335578/assignments/14889567)

The Persuasive Essay paper should be 5-7 pages long (approximately 1250-1750 words). You should use at least 5-7 sources, at least 3 of which should be scholarly sources. 

Your paper should have an interesting title and a hook to grab your reader's attention. You should state a clear thesis and support it with evidence, carefully engaging with the counter-arguments. 

Please use MLA format. Please see this link for MLA format examples: https://owl.purdue.edu/owl/research_and_citation/mla_style/mla_formatting_and_style_guide/documents/20180702110400_747-2.pdf

Please print your Persuasive Paper and bring it to class. Your paper should be about 4-6 pages long (approximately 1250-1750 words). You should use 5-6 sources, at least 3 of which should be scholarly sources. 

Your paper should have an interesting title and a hook to grab your reader's attention. You should state a clear thesis and support it with evidence, carefully engaging with naysayers. 

Please use MLA format. See this link for MLA format examples: https://owl.purdue.edu/owl/research_and_citation/mla_style/mla_formatting_and_style_guide/documents/20180702110400_747-2.pdf

-----------------
Vital Information
-----------------

* Audience: English 150 Instructor

* Purpose: Demonstrate your ability to (1) integrate sources according to academic standards and (2) analyze your experience with the writing process in ENG 150, and (3) provide evidence for how this course helped you become a more effective communicator.

* Length: 300-550 words (about 1.5-2 pages)

------------
Instructions
------------

* Brainstorm a response to the following questions:

* What misconceptions or concerns did you have about writing before taking ENG 150?

* What have you learned this semester about the writing process?

* What have you learned about how to be an effective communicator?

* Study the following resources and choose quotes that connect with your learning experience in ENG 150. You must use at least one quote from L. Lennie Irvin's "What Is 'Academic' Writing?" and one quote from E. Shelley Reid’s “Ten Ways to Think About Writing: Metaphoric Musings for College Writing Students.” You are, of course, welcome to include more than just one quote from each article and to summarize or paraphrase ideas from the articles as well.

*

* [What Is Academic Writing_Irvin_ENG150 Common Assessment Excerpt.pdf] (https://byui.instructure.com/courses/335578/files/148015482?wrap=1) 

* [Ten Ways To Think About Writing_Common Assessment Excerpt.pdf] (https://byui.instructure.com/courses/335578/files/148015484?wrap=1) 

* Begin writing a 1.5–2 page reflection paper. Follow these instructions as you do so:

* Write a rough draft or outline of your reflection. There are many ways to organize a reflection essay, but the basic organization should include the following.

* Introduction: Describe your mindset at the beginning of ENG 150, and share some of the misconceptions or initial concerns you may have had. You may or may not use a quote as part of the introduction.

* Body Paragraph: Describe what you learned and how it helped you overcome a misconception or concern about writing. You may or may not incorporate a quote from an outside source here, but you will need to include two quotes from different sources somewhere in the reflection.

* Body Paragraph: Describe another thing you learned and how it helped you overcome either the same misconception/concern or a different misconception/concern about writing.

* More Body Paragraphs: Add more descriptions of your learning and growth as needed/desired.

* Conclusion: Briefly summarize the most important things you learned, and describe how you plan to use what you've learned beyond this class. In other words, how has this class helped you to be an effective communicator in future writing situations?

* Last, but not least, consider formatting. What have you learned about expectations for academic style (usually MLA or APA)? What have you learned about citing sources?  Be sure to show (and not just tell) your instructor what you’ve learned.

* Submit your completed reflection by the due date.

Helpful Hints
-------------

* Be sure to support your ideas about learning to write in ENG 150 with meaningful and specific evidence from your experiences in the course. In other words, don't just say, "This class taught me how to write." Instead, give specific examples of what you didn't know (or thought you knew) and then describe how and why you changed throughout the semester. Be sure to mention specifics like assigned readings, homework, conferences, and other activities that either helped (or didn't help) you along the way.

* Be sure to format the citations correctly at the end of your essay. The final citations for the articles should look like this:

APA Format

Irvin, L. L. (2010). What is "academic" writing? In C. Lowe and P. Zemaliansky (Eds.), Writing Spaces: Readings on Writing, vol. 1. Parlor Press.

Reid, E. S. (2011). Ten ways to think about writing: Metaphoric musings for college writing students. In C. Lowe and P. Zemaliansky (Eds.), Writing Spaces: Readings on Writing, vol. 2. Parlor Press.

MLA Format

Irvin, L. Lennie. “What Is 'Academic' Writing?” Writing Spaces: Readings on Writing, edited by Charles Lowe and Pavel Zemlianksky, vol. 1, Parlor Press, 2010. WritingSpaces.org, https://writingspaces.org/past-volumes/a-students-guide-to-collaborative-writing-technologies/.

Reid, E. Shelley. “Ten Ways to Think about Writing: Metaphoric Musings for College Writing Students. Writing Spaces: Readings on Writing, edited by Charles Lowe and Pavel Zemlianksky, vol. 2, Parlor Press, 2010. WritingSpaces.org, https://writingspaces.org/past-volumes/a-students-guide-to-collaborative-writing-technologies/.

REL 122.description:
--------
Overview
--------

This activity will help you become acquainted with your classmates so it will be easier to collaborate and learn from each other throughout the course. Use this activity to really begin to get to know each other and connect with your online classmates. Share your personality; have fun!

------------
Instructions
------------

* Introduce yourself to the class in a few short paragraphs (approximately 100–150 words). Select Reply to begin your post. In your thread think about including:

* Something unique or something you particularly like about yourself.

* Since others won't be able to see you, how can you help others get an idea of who you are?

* Why are you taking the course?

* What do you hope to get from this course?

* How do you think you will be changed by this course over the semester?

* What you think will provide maximum growth in this course?

* What can you commit to doing to help others be successful?

* After you are finished with your post, read at least 4–6 of your classmates' posts.

* Respond to at least three with whom you find you have something in common, or who interests you. You might explain a connection you have (perhaps you have lived in the same area, served in the same mission, share common hobbies, etc.), or you might have a question about something they said. Respond sincerely (50–75 words each.)

* NOTE: Early posts are likely to get more traffic. Think about trying to find posts with fewer responses and responding to those.

* As people respond to your posts throughout the week, briefly answer them. Reply to people (at least three) who comment on your post.

--------
Overview
--------

In this activity, you will read a talk given by President James E. Faust, reflect on it and share your thoughts. This assignment will help you to reflect and set goals for the semester in this course. The insights you gain from this assignment will be helpful as you complete your weekly assignments. Your instructor will grade and provide feedback on this assignment.

------------
Instructions
------------

* Read President James E. Faust, [Joseph Smith and the Book of Mormon] (https://www.lds.org/ensign/1996/01/joseph-smith-and-the-book-of-mormon?lang=eng), Ensign, Jan. 1996.

* Please write a one-paragraph response to each of the following questions:

* What role has the Book of Mormon and its teachings played in your life?

* What do you hope to gain from your study of the second half of the Book of Mormon this semester?

* What insights did you gain from the above article?

* Submit your paragraph here in this assignment.

NOTE: Be sure to complete all the instructions in this activity before submitting it.

In this activity, you will take a quiz on your understanding of the course. The purpose of this activity is to help you become familiar with what is expected of you during this course. This quiz will also help solidify your understanding of how the course is laid out. Your instructor will be available online to answer any questions that you may have.

----------
Conditions
----------

* Ensure that you have completed the [W01 Prepare: Welcome to REL 122] (https://byui.instructure.com/courses/341216/pages/w01-prepare-welcome-to-fdrel-122) activity.

* Complete this quiz by selecting the start button below.

--------
Overview
--------

This discussion board is an opportunity for you to share scriptural insights and to learn from your classmates and instructor. Three posts are required throughout the week, designed to build upon each other to help you better understand and apply the scriptures in your life. Your instructor will also be involved in the discussion.

NOTE: Though the actual due date and end date for this discussion fall on the same days as other activities this week, each post in this discussion has a recommended day of the week to post in order for it to be most meaningful for you and your classmates.

------------
Instructions
------------

* To complete this activity, you will share three posts throughout the week by their posted due dates. Follow the individual instructions and examples for the three posts below.

* To see specific grading criteria, select the [3 Dots.] (https://byui.instructure.com/courses/341216/files/147260780/preview)  button at the top of this window and choose Show rubric.

Post 01 Scriptural Insight
--------------------------

Instructions
------------

For this discussion to be most meaningful for you and your classmates, we recommend completing it by Tuesday (mountain time).

* Copy and Paste (or type) a passage of scripture from the assigned reading that teaches a meaningful principle.

* Add the reference to the scripture passage so others can know where to go to find it.

* Identify or restate that principle in your own words and put it in bold font. See example below.

* Briefly discuss that principle and its significance to you.

Example
-------

Student 01: "Therefore go, my son, and thou shalt be favored of the Lord because thou hast not murmured."–1 Nephi 3:6. I love 1 Nephi 3:7, but in reading 1 Nephi 3:6 this time, I noticed something I hadn't focused on before. Nephi isn't just blessed for being willing to return to Jerusalem; he's blessed because he does so with a good attitude. After all, Laman and Lemuel make the trip, but they do so begrudgingly. This makes me think that real obedience isn't just completing the action the Lord requires, like going home teaching, he also requires that we obey with the right attitude, like going home teaching joyfully with a desire to bless and uplift others.

 

Post 02 Increased Understanding
-------------------------------

Instructions
------------

For this discussion to be most meaningful for you and your classmates, we recommend completing it by Thursday (mountain time).

For the second post, you will reply to a classmate's post. Try to add further insight or understanding into one of the posts made by your classmates by sharing a related scripture, or a quote from a church leader and then explaining how you feel it adds additional insight or understanding to the scripture or principle being discussed.

Example
-------

Student 02: This is a great insight. It is very hard not to murmur when we face a difficult task that we wish would be a lot easier. In Nephi's case, I learned something in studying the Institute manual that helped me realize how great his sacrifice was in making the trip back to Jerusalem. I just thought it was a three-day trip one way because 1 Nephi 2:6 talks about when Lehi "had traveled three days in the wilderness . . ." But the Institute Manual pointed out that Lehi and his family first "came down by the borders near the shore of the Red Sea" (1 Nephi 5:6), which is "about 180 miles through a hot, barren country infested anciently by many marauders." Combined with three days of traveling in the wilderness, this means that the whole trip was "at least a twelve-to-fourteen-day trip one way." This was not an easy task, but Nephi does not murmur and I think it is because of his great faith in the Lord and desire to do what was right that he was able to tackle this challenge with a good attitude.

 

Post 03 Personal Application
----------------------------

Instructions
------------

For the third post, you will reply to a classmate's post. Pick a post that you can make a personal application to. You can either share a brief story of when you have seen that principle in your life, identify a way you are currently trying to live that principle or share an example of a friend or family member who has exemplified that principle to you.

Example
-------

Student 03: I can imagine being quite frustrated if I had first been asked by my dad to leave our city on a 14-day trip and then abruptly being asked to travel back 14 days, retrieve something we left behind, and then being asked to return for another 14-day trip—that's 42 days of traveling! I might think it was a big waste of time and a huge inconvenience. In my life, the prophet has not asked me to accomplish a task like that, but he has asked me to serve as a visiting teacher. I admit that sometimes I feel like this assignment can feel like an inconvenience for me since I have very little free time as a student right now. However, I know that when I have a good attitude about this assignment, it has helped me to love the sisters I visit and to have a better spirit as I've shared messages with them. Sometimes obedience will be inconvenient, but it will always be the right thing to do.

 

NOTE: Be sure to complete all instructions in this activity before considering it complete.

Overview
--------

The purpose of this activity is to help you focus on significant principles and themes within this week's Book of Mormon scripture block. NOTE: Be sure to complete all instructions in this activity before submitting it.

For this project, you will create a lesson plan for a Family Home Evening and teach it to family or friends. This activity is intended to give you an opportunity to plan, teach, testify, and increase your gospel understanding. Not only will these skills and experiences greatly benefit you and your future family, but they will also provide many meaningful experiences with friends and family now. Your instructor will be available online to answer any questions that you may have.

--------
Overview
--------

In this activity, you will share a scriptural insight with your friends or family using the study materials from the past two weeks. The purpose of this activity is to deepen understanding through sharing insight with others. Your instructor will grade your submission, and provide feedback.

------------
Instructions
------------

NOTE: Even though this assignment isn't due until the end of the week, it is important that you get started on this activity early in the week. If you are meeting face-to-face, you will need to set up a time to meet. If you are sharing by way of social media, email, etc. you will need to post early in the week to give time for conversation to happen.

When you share your insight you should do the following:

* Identify one insight from your personal study of the Book of Mormon over the past two weeks ([W02] (https://byui.instructure.com/courses/341216/pages/w02-study-readings) and [W03] (https://byui.instructure.com/courses/341216/pages/w03-study-readings)) that you want to share. This should include a scripture passage or prophetic quote, and your explanation of why it is important or how it is relevant in your life.

* Share your insight! You could talk with a friend, Skype your family, call your grandma, post something on social media, send someone a letter or email, or make a blog entry. Try to generate a discussion with others about what you shared and why it is important.

* Reflect and report on your experience. Download and complete the [Share It! Template] (https://byui.instructure.com/courses/341216/files/148340976?wrap=1).

* Submit the completed document in this assignment.

CSE 131.description:
* Task: Read the syllabus, look through the course web site, and take the syllabus quiz.

* Purpose: To understand how grading happens, where to find information, and what the course policies are.

* Time: It should take about an hour to complete this activity.

------------
Instructions
------------

* This first activity is a scavenger hunt. All the answers can be found by looking through the I-Learn site. You can take the quiz five times; you should stop once you get 100%. You may wish to have two windows open when doing this activity: one with the quiz, and one with the I-Learn site. This should make passing the quiz much easier. This is an open-book quiz.

--------
Overview
--------

* Task: Write a program in Python.

* Purpose: Review your Python syntax and learn how to turn stuff in.

* Time: It should take about three hours to complete this activity.

------------
Instructions
------------

* Read the [Lab 01: Tic-Tac-Toe instructions] (https://content.byui.edu/file/68c35474-e9e5-4e96-8900-c195bb668770/1/Ponder/131.01.Ponder.html).

* Create a Python program to represent the problem definition.

* Create a short video demonstrating the execution of your program.

* Submit the program and a link to the video here.

* Task: Read Chapter 1.0: Structure Chart in the textbook and complete the reading quiz.

* Purpose: Demonstrate familiarity with structure charts.

* Time: It should take about an hour to complete this activity. Previous semesters have averaged 35 minutes.

------------
Instructions
------------

* Please read Chapter 1.0: Structure Chart.

* Take this reading quiz. You can take the quiz five times. This is an open-book quiz.

* The answers will be displayed after the due date.

--------
Overview
--------

* Task: Create a structure chart, pseudocode, and a flowchart.

* Purpose: Learn how to design a program before writing the code.

* Time: It should take about three hours to complete this activity.

------------
Instructions
------------

* Read the [Lab 02: Calendar Design instructions.] (https://content.byui.edu/file/68c35474-e9e5-4e96-8900-c195bb668770/1/Ponder/131.02.Ponder.html)

* Create a structure chart representing a program to display a calendar.

* Create pseudocode representing one function of the design.

* Submit the three deliverables here as a single PDF.

* Task: Read Chapter 1.1: Data Flow Diagrams in the textbook and take the quiz.

* Purpose: Demonstrate fact- and comprehension-level understanding of the topics in the chapter.

* Time: It should take about an hour to complete this activity.  Previous semesters have averaged 58 minutes.

------------
Instructions
------------

* Please read Chapter 1.1: Data Flow Diagrams from the textbook.

* You can take the quiz five times. The answers will be displayed after the due date.

--------
Overview

* Purpose: Learn how to create a moderately complex program with many functions.

* Time: It should take about three hours to complete this activity.

------------
Instructions

* Submit the code and a link to the video here.

* Create a structure chart representing the entire Sudoku program.

* Create a data flow diagram representing the entire Sudoku program.

* Create pseudocode or flowcharts of two functions.

* Submit everything here as a single file.

* Task: Read Chapter 1.3: Coupling in the textbook and take the quiz.

------------

------------

* Please read Chapter 1.4: Drivers from the textbook.

--------
Overview

* Time: It should take about three hours to complete this activity.

------------
Instructions
------------

* Read the [Lab 06: Sudoku Program instructions.] (https://content.byui.edu/file/68c35474-e9e5-4e96-8900-c195bb668770/1/Ponder/131.06.Ponder.html)

* Purpose: Demonstrate fact- and comprehension-level understanding of the topics in the chapter.

------------
Instructions
------------

--------
Overview

------------

Instructions

* Time: It should take about three hours to complete this activity.

------------

------------

CSE 199R.description:
------------------
Portfolio Showcase
------------------

 Purpose
--------

Demonstrate ability to design, craft, and implement a project. The purpose of the project is not to "complete" the project, but show good progress with initiative to complete later on.

 

 Tasks
------

*

* An introduction, including a brief sales pitch of the idea

* A demonstration of your project

* The next steps

* Allow the class to provide constructive feedback

* Submit the class feedback

--------
Overview
--------

* Purpose: Learn about and practice the principle of Encapsulation.

* Task: Complete the [Version Control Learning Activity] (https://byui-cse.github.io/cse210-course-2023/unit01/prepare-version-control.html).

----------
Submission
----------

* Push your learning activity work to your course GitHub repository.

* Submit this quiz to report on the learning activity that you completed.

--------
Overview
--------

* Purpose: The purpose of this assignment is to help you learn the basics of the C# language that you will use throughout the semester.

* Task: Complete the first two of the five small C# programming assignments.

------------
Instructions
------------

* Complete each of the following assignments:

* [C# Prep 1—Variables and Input/Output] (https://byui-cse.github.io/cse210-course-2023/unit01/csharp-1.html)

* [C# Prep 2—Conditionals] (https://byui-cse.github.io/cse210-course-2023/unit01/csharp-2.html)

* (In the next week, you will finish C# Prep 3–5)

* To complete each assignment you must:

* Finish all steps in the assignment instructions.

* Review the Sample Solution.

* Push your code to GitHub.

* Return here to report your progress.

--------
Overview
--------

Review the description below for a quick overview of this activity.

* Task: Introduce yourself to your peers and to your instructor. Answer the following questions in your post below. 

* Purpose: This will allow you to get to know your peers and instructor a little better.

* Instructor: Your instructor will read your posts and participate in the discussion.

------------
Instructions
------------

To successfully complete this activity, carefully follow these steps:

* Update your Canvas profile, and be sure your information is correct. [Include a personal photograph (Links to an external site.)] (https://community.canvaslms.com/docs/DOC-10599-4212710334) that will help others know you better and identify you when you begin working in groups later next week.

* Your initial post will consist of two paragraphs.

* In the first paragraph, write a brief introduction of yourself. Remember that the purpose of this original post is to drive conversation; be creative, and share things that you feel are interesting about yourself or that you are passionate about. You must include at least the following, but you may choose to add anything you feel pertinent.

* Name.

* Hometown, state, and country.

* Something interesting about you or that you like to do.

* What you hope to get out of CSE 210. 

* In the second paragraph, talk about why you are taking this class and what you hope to do with the things you learn.  Share some of your experiences with programming, interesting things you have learned, or things that you hope to learn. 

Response Posts
--------------

Complete the response post steps by the end of the week.

For full credit, do the following:

* Respond to at least three of your fellow students' introductory posts. Your response post must address both the introduction paragraph and the teamwork paragraph.

* Your posts must contribute to the conversation. A simple “I agree” or “That’s cool” alone does not contribute.
